context: The difference in the median number of VOCs detected in all samples between indoors (classroom and kindergarten pooled) and outdoors is statistically significant (p =0.01). Toluene and benzene were the abundant compounds in all campaigns, unlike indoors; however, benzene had higher mean concentrations than toluene in two campaigns for outdoors (Fig. 3 ). In addition, neither of the two compounds reached the two-digit concentrations in the five campaigns, and at least one was at one-digit level in two of the four remaining campaigns. The other frequently detected high-concentration (≥1μg/m3) compounds were 1,3-dichlorobenzene, p,m-xylene, and naphthalene. The number of abundant species and their concentrations were lower outdoors compared to indoor air. Table 1 also presents the mean toluene/benzene and toluene/TVOC51 ratio values, and TVOC51 concentrations for playgrounds. The median outdoor TVOC51 level was lower than the indoor level (p <0.001).

llm_generation.summary: In this context, 1,4-dichlorobenzene and 4-xylene are both mentioned as volatile organic compounds (VOCs) detected in air samples, but there is no direct discussion of their relationship or interaction. They are part of a broader analysis comparing indoor and outdoor air quality, with 4-xylene being one of the frequently detected compounds alongside others like toluene and benzene. However, their specific roles or interactions are not elaborated upon.
